data.title: Intersecting Mediums: How Video Games are the New Frontier for Capitalizing on Movie IP
data.meta_description: In the ever-evolving entertainment industry, the synergy between movies and games has never been more prominent. The integration of popular movie intellectual property (IP) into the world of video…
data.text:
In the ever-evolving entertainment industry, the synergy between movies and games has never been more prominent. The integration of popular movie intellectual property (IP) into the world of video games has become a defining trend. This convergence represents a dynamic fusion of storytelling mediums, where beloved narratives and iconic characters from the silver screen are reimagined in interactive digital landscapes. The allure of playing an active role in these familiar universes, once exclusively confined to passive viewing, has captivated audiences and developers alike.

Video Games are No Longer an Afterthought for Hollywood

In the past, adapting movie IP into video games was typically an afterthought rather than a primary focus for Hollywood studios, especially considering the scarcity of technology and development resources. In the early 1980s, the video game market was still in its infancy, and game developers were primarily focused on creating original gameplay experiences. The technical limitations of early gaming platforms made it challenging to recreate the cinematic experiences of popular movies accurately. These early adaptations often struggled to capture the essence of the films they were based on, leading to mixed reviews and consumer dissatisfaction. Reasons varied, but often the games felt rushed technically and in story, which left the viewer feeling unsatisfied compared to the movie.

Atari’s “Raiders of the Lost Ark,” released in 1982, marked a groundbreaking moment in video game history as the first game based on a movie license. The game bridged Hollywood and the video game world, setting the stage for future collaborations. The game took a year and a half to develop, and the time was well spent, as reviews lauded the gameplay’s complexity and difficulty. While the graphics at the time were considered standard or average for the period, the quality of the game itself offset any issues players might have had with the technical aspects of the game. This game set a precedent for future interactive projects, showing the viability of video games to extend the lifecycle of popular IP.

However, Atari’s “E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial”, also released in 1982, showcased the risks and frailty of movie-based games, especially if there was not meticulous attention given to maintaining the quality of the game. Rushed to coincide with the holiday season, it suffered from hurried development, unclear direction, and Atari 2600 technical limitations. The game was developed from scratch and finished in just five weeks. Upon release, the game frustrated players, and its graphics and sound disappointed. The “E.T.” game’s failure was a watershed moment for movie-based games, emphasizing quality and thoughtful game design over a famous license. This lesson reshaped how developers and studios approached such games, leading to more cautious, strategic development. The game’s poor reception and market saturation contributed to the 1983 video game industry crash, prompting changes like quality control standards and a shift toward innovation in game design.

It wasn’t until decades later in the business’s evolution, as technology improved and gaming became a more mainstream form of entertainment, that the potential profitability of movie-based video games began to re-emerge. Video games have evolved dramatically in terms of visual effects, now showcasing incredibly realistic graphics, detailed textures, and lifelike character models thanks to advancements in rendering technologies. Additionally, the improvement in hardware and software has resulted in smoother gameplay, higher resolutions, and better overall performance across various gaming platforms. As gaming consoles and PCs became more capable of delivering immersive and visually impressive experiences, game developers started to see the value in aligning with successful movie franchises, especially in the 2010s. Primarily driven by advancements in gaming technology and the desire to engage existing fan bases, this phenomenon reshaped the landscape of film and video games, and how the two are produced and marketed.

One prominent subset of video game adaptations during the 2010s was the emergence of superhero movie adaptations. Games like “Batman: Arkham City” and “Spider-Man” allowed players to step into the shoes of superheroes, bringing iconic narratives to life in the gaming business. These adaptations captured the essence of the characters and successfully replicated the adrenaline-pumping action sequences that fans had come to expect from the films. The LEGO video game series further exemplified this trend by adapting various movie franchises into a family-friendly and visually appealing gaming experience. Titles like “LEGO Harry Potter: Years 5–7”, “LEGO The Lord of the Rings”, and “LEGO Marvel Super Heroes” amalgamated beloved movie worlds with the trademark LEGO charm, appealing to a broad audience including younger gamers and families. Additionally, games like “Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor” and its sequel “Shadow of War” provided an immersive experience within the universe of J.R.R. Tolkien’s Middle-earth, drawing inspiration from “The Hobbit” and “The Lord of the Rings” film trilogies.

Games like “Mad Max” and “Jurassic World Evolution” presented immersive worlds inspired by their respective movie franchises. “Mad Max” embraced vehicular combat in a post-apocalyptic setting, while “Jurassic World Evolution” allowed players to create and manage their own dinosaur-themed amusement park, drawing from the iconic “Jurassic Park” and “Jurassic World” films. These adaptations successfully captured the essence of the original movies while leveraging the interactive nature of video games to provide fans with engaging and immersive experiences.

Maximizing IP through Additional Revenue Streams

Today, with advancements in technology, high-resolution graphics, and expansive storytelling capabilities, video game adaptations of movies are often carefully planned and integrated into a film’s marketing strategy. These adaptations can be significant revenue generators, tapping into the existing fan base of a movie and providing players with an opportunity to explore and interact with cinematic worlds. “Star Wars Jedi: Survivor” (Star Wars Franchise) and “Hogwarts Legacy” (Harry Potter Franchise), which both came out in 2023, have emerged as pivotal examples of how video games based on iconic movie franchises can raise the bar and, in some cases, outperform their cinematic counterparts, artistically and financially.

These games have demonstrated that investing in high-quality game development within established movie franchises can yield substantial financial returns. “Star Wars Jedi: Survivor”, for instance, generated significant revenue, with sales figures that surpassed the box office earnings of several “Star Wars” films. The game has been so successful that reports show that Microsoft is expected to offer $300 million to put “Star Wars Jedi: Survivor” on Xbox Game Pass. Similarly, “Hogwarts Legacy” achieved remarkable profitability, outearning some of the “Harry Potter” movies. In May 2023, the most recent report stated that “Hogwarts Legacy” had sold over 15 million copies to earn over $1 billion. This financial success underscores how consumers are willing to invest their time and money into interactive experiences that allow them to immerse themselves in the worlds of their favorite movies.

Warner Bros. Games (WBG), Warner Bros.’ gaming division, has emerged as a category leader in the realm of video games based on movie IP due to its unique blend of creative vision, extensive catalog of iconic franchises, and a commitment to delivering high-quality gaming experiences. With a rich history in film and gaming, WBG leverages its unparalleled access to movie franchises, including Harry Potter, Batman, and Middle-earth, allowing it to create immersive, narrative-driven games that resonate with fans. Its ability to maintain faithful adaptations while introducing innovative gameplay mechanics sets the division apart. WBG is known for collaborating with top-tier developers, ensuring that these titles are not just cinematic but also technically impressive, pushing the boundaries of what’s possible in the industry.

Sony Interactive Entertainment (SIE), Sony’s video game division, has carved out a prominent position in the video game business, particularly in the realm of adapting movies into interactive experiences, and vice versa. With an extensive portfolio that includes titles like “Spider-Man”, “Uncharted”, and “The Last of Us”, Sony has leveraged its position as a major player in film and gaming to craft exceptional movie-to-video game adaptations. What sets SIE apart is its in-house development studios, such as Naughty Dog, Insomniac Games, and Santa Monica Studio, which possess a profound understanding of storytelling and technical prowess. This allows Sony to ensure that its adaptations are not just faithful to the source material but also push the boundaries of immersive gameplay. SIE’s commitment to delivering cinematic narratives and breathtaking graphics within its games has garnered it recognition as a leader in the industry. Another big advantage Sony has is its ownership of the PlayStation brand. With direct access to a leading gaming platform, SIE can seamlessly integrate its movie franchises into PlayStation, leveraging established gaming expertise and a dedicated audience base. This ownership enables SIE to tailor and optimize the gaming experience for its movies, ensuring a cohesive and immersive connection between the two mediums.

The Increasing Popularity of Interactive Divisions in Hollywood

Major studios aren’t the only group looking to capitalize on this growing demand for premium IP-based video games. Smaller IP owners, like Bad Robot, are capitalizing upon their IP and entering the video game production business. In 2020, Bad Robot Games, the video game unit of J.J. Abrams’ Bad Robot, launched an in-house game development studio. With several projects in development, Bad Robot Games will create gaming destinations whose worlds and stories can live across multiple mediums based on internally developed and acquired IP. Bad Robot, unlike Warner Bros., does not have a video game production studio but will partner with developers to turn IP into premium video games. While splitting the revenues with its partners, this production structure allows Bad Robot Games to pursue more opportunities to capitalize on IP.

Blumhouse Games, a relatively new player in the video game industry, has quickly made a name for itself as a promising contender in the movie-to-video game adaptation arena. Leveraging the extensive and successful portfolio of Blumhouse Productions in the horror genre, known for hit films like “Insidious” and “The Purge”, Blumhouse Games has brought its expertise in creating spine-chilling cinematic experiences to the world of interactive storytelling. Its focus on translating horror IP into video games allows the unit to tap into a dedicated and passionate fan base. Collaborations with talented developers have ensured that the transition from the big screen to the gaming console is smooth, retaining the essence of its movie IP while offering fresh and engaging gameplay mechanics. Blumhouse Games is gaining recognition for its commitment to delivering horror experiences that keep players on the edge of their seats, making it a notable player in the business, especially within the niche of horror-themed video games.

The profitability of these games has further cemented the idea that adapting movie IP into video games can be more financially rewarding than the movies themselves. It has become evident that video game adaptations can tap into the dedicated fan bases of these franchises, offering immersive experiences that extend and enrich the storytelling universe, all while proving to be lucrative ventures for developers and studios alike. Studios with premium movie IP will continue to take advantage of the constantly growing video game market, a larger and faster-growing market than the film business.

The future of video game adaptations of movie IP holds immense promise, particularly as the video game business continues to evolve. As technology advances, gaming experiences will become increasingly immersive and sophisticated, offering an ideal canvas for translating iconic movie franchises into interactive worlds. Developers are now equipped with the tools and expertise to faithfully capture the essence of cinematic narratives, not merely as passive observers but as active participants. The line between movies and video games is blurring as cinematic storytelling techniques, high-quality graphics, and realistic motion capture are seamlessly integrated into gaming experiences. This convergence will provide players with unparalleled opportunities to step into the shoes of their favorite characters, explore familiar universes, and shape their destinies within these narratives.

Moreover, as the video game business grows and continues to gain mass adoption, collaborations between movie studios and game developers will become more deliberate. The financial success of games like “Star Wars Jedi: Survivor” and “Hogwarts Legacy” has solidified the profitability of such endeavors. This financial incentive will likely spur even more ambitious adaptations in the future. Established premium content investors, like MCT, looking to continue to profit from strategic investments in IP, will benefit from continued access to new content, leveraging the lucrative revenue streams ignited by video games. The future holds the potential for groundbreaking innovations in storytelling, gameplay mechanics, and interactive experiences that redefine how we engage with our favorite movies. In essence, the evolution of the video game business has and will continue to shape the future of movie adaptations, offering fans exciting and immersive extensions of their beloved cinematic universes.
